messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] ? for Sandra / NM
messages.msgSnippet: Really, local stuff shouldn t be on lists like this. None of it s new.  It s as easily ignored as it ever was.  This would be better handled on the
messages.messageBody:
Really, local stuff shouldn't be on lists like this.

None of it's new. It's as easily ignored as it ever was. <g>

This would be better handled on the unschoolarama list, or by e-
mail. My e-mail address is on most of the webpages: http://
sandradodd.com

Sandra

messages.subject: ? for Sandra / NM
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Sandra.  It is Crystal and Sorscha in NM.  Do you know anything about this?  If you wish to keep this off list, you may email off line.  Thanks for any
messages.messageBody:
Hi Sandra. It is Crystal and Sorscha in NM. Do you know anything
about this? If you wish to keep this off list, you may email off
line. Thanks for any information.
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++
> Message: 1
> Date: Sun, 05 Feb 2006 16:38:55 -0000
> > Subject: update
>
> Hi! I began homeschooling my children again mid October 2005 and
> since then there have been some changes to the requirements as
> indicated on the New Mexico Public Education Department: Now in
New
> Mexico Homeschooling parents must have their High School Diploma or
> GED kept with the immunization records.
(http://nmhomeschools.org
> click on "Most Requested" tab then the last selection
> is "Homeschools".)
>
> Also, now a school calendar is required for homeschoolers
with
> at least 180 days of school. There are many examples of school
> calendars on the web. To make this task easier time and date.com
has
> a FREE and excellent calendar feature which also allows one to
> customize holidays among other features. (www.timeanddate.com)
>
> the New Mexico Public Education Department is stating now
that
> they will no longer accept written notification from homeschoolers
> with a requirement to notify online annually. (interesting)
>
> --------------------------------------------------------------------
--
> personal note:
>
> New Mexico Public Schools rankings and performance are among
the
> worst n the country. It is important for homeschoolers in New
Mexico
> to form a unnited front together and keep a WATCH DOG monitoring
such
> changes in the future.
>
